title: Kinetic energy - object with constant acceleration

content.question: An object moves in the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction with constant acceleration. Its path is described by the position <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> versus time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> graph shown in the figure. The object’s kinetic energy at time <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is <math alttext="K sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and its kinetic energy at time <math alttext="t sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> is <math alttext="K sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math>. Which of the following correctly compares <math alttext="K sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="K sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> and provides valid justification?

choices.label: <math alttext="K sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="K sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> are the same because the direction of velocity does not affect an object’s kinetic energy.

<math alttext="K sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="K sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> are the same because the acceleration is constant and therefore the kinetic energy is the same at all times between <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="t sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math>.

<math alttext="K sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="K sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> are different because the object is moving in opposite directions at these times.

<math alttext="K sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="K sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> are different because the object is moving with a constant acceleration between <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="t sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="K sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="K sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> are the same because the direction of velocity does not affect an object’s kinetic energy.
